revised_title: Investigating Lunar-Diurnal Variation of Magnetic Declination
tldr: The author examines the hourly records of magnetic declination at the Flagstaff Observatory in Melbourne, Victoria, from 1858 to 1863, and discovers that the lunar-diurnal variation of the magnetic declination is influenced by both the sun and the moon. The study reveals that the variation is more regular when the declinations of the sun and moon are of the same name.
